text:
GARY PISANO: Creative
construction offers
a few key lessons.

The first, when it
comes to innovation,
big doesn't have to be bad.

Second, to be a
successful innovator,

you don't have to
be a disruptor.

There's many different
types of innovation.

And the right ones for your
organization and your industry
will vary.

Third, you've often heard
the advice eat your own lunch

before someone else
does when confronting
a potential disruption.

That's not necessarily
always true.

And I want creative
construction to get

people to think much
more strategically

about these threats and
challenges from disruption.

Fourth, best practices aren't
always your best friend.

When it comes to innovation
practice, there are trade-offs.

Finally, innovative cultures,
they're not all fun and games.

We often emphasize
things like tolerance

for failure and collaboration
and freedom to speak up.

All really attractive
attributes of an organization

that many of us
want to be part of.

But to be an innovative company,
to have an innovative culture,

also requires a set
of behaviors like

intolerance for incompetence,
high levels of accountability,
brutal candor.

These are often
things that many of us
are much less comfortable with.
